thread.title: Royals' Jeremy Guthrie recalls growing up in Oregon town rocked by shooting
thread.title_full: Royals' Jeremy Guthrie recalls growing up in Oregon town rocked by shooting

title: Royals' Jeremy Guthrie recalls growing up in Oregon town rocked by shooting
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Royals' Jeremy Guthrie recalls growing up in Oregon town rocked by shooting Kansas City Royals pitcher Jeremy Guthrie fondly remembers those days growing up in Oregon ‚Äî riding his bike all around Roseburg. Post to Facebook Royals' Jeremy Guthrie recalls growing up in Oregon town rocked by shooting Kansas City Royals pitcher Jeremy Guthrie fondly remembers those days growing up in Oregon ‚Äî riding his bike all around Roseburg.  //on.kgw.com/1FKfe4D   Royals' Jeremy Guthrie recalls growing up in Oregon town rocked by shooting A tragic day at Umpqua Community College near Roseburg as 10 people were killed in a mass shooting at the school. Associated Press 10:31 p.m. PDT October 1, 2015 Sep 1, 2015; Kansas City, MO, USA; Kansas City Royals relief pitcher Jeremy Guthrie (11) delivers a pitch against the Detroit Tigers in the eighth inning at Kauffman Stadium. Detroit won the game 6-5. Mandatory Credit: John Rieger-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: John Rieger, John Rieger-USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT 9 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
CHICAGO (AP) ‚Äî Kansas City Royals pitcher Jeremy Guthrie fondly remembers those days growing up in Oregon ‚Äî riding his bike all around Roseburg, going to the local swimming pool and cheering on the basketball team at Umpqua Community College. 
All those memories came flooding back after a gunman opened fire at the school on Thursday, killing at least nine people before dying in a shootout with police. 
"It's a very small community," Guthrie said of the town where he was born and lived until he was 12. "My mom spent time there. I don't remember ‚Äî I was so young ‚Äî if she was going to school there or if she was helping out there, but my brothers and I used to go swimming there at the swimming pool that you can see in those aerial photos. We used to watch basketball games there for the local team." Another tragic shooting. This one hits home being from Roseburg. Spent a lot of time on UCC campus as a kid. üôè https://t.co/9NerF6sCPA ‚Äî Jeremy Guthrie (@TheRealJGuts) October 1, 2015 
"So we spent a lot of time there and it's part of the community. I'm sure they're going through a lot of pain. I'm sure a lot of people and families are connected to some of the victims," he said. 
Guthrie's father sold cars in the Roseburg area for about 20 years, and the left-hander said he still has several aunts, uncles and cousins in the region about 180 miles south of Portland. He stayed in Oregon after he moved and visited his hometown often for sporting events. 
He said he heard about the mass shooting when an old friend sent him a text message to express his sadness. 
"You keep them in your prayers and just hope that at some point in time, we, as a society, and as people, can learn to cope with struggles and difficulties and challenges in our lives in a different way," Guthrie said before the Royals played the Chicago White Sox. 
"We obviously all have the ability to go out and do harm, whether it's with a gun or whether it's through other forms of violence, that's never the answer," he said. "Unfortunately, we've seen too many people resort to that in recent times. All of us go through struggles; all of us have our challenges. Maybe we can show a little more love and compassion to those who are going through other things. Hopefully the end result is that we can stop having to witness these types of tragedies."
